reviewText: They dont make family films anymore like this...Ive heard of it, but i never had the chance to see it.Good old Jimmy Durante.... this guy is a classic act. Use to seehim on Ed Sullivan or other shows and we always enjoyed him, hissiging his jokes...So this movie which depicts different characters which is setin the good old no money ..depression days delivers the package.With a excellent cast,good storetelling and Rupert, this moviecan be watched by anybody, and its guaranteed that it will entertain you and leave you with a smile.
summary: Cant lose on this classic tale.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Great Rupert" aka "A Christmas Wish" (1950) is a long-overlooked Christmas comedy classic. Consistently, this Jimmy Durante gem receives 5-Star ratings - yet, it never shows up on TV. Don't let the budget price fool you - if you like 1940s & 1950s Christmas movies, you'll wonder where this one has been all these years.Former vaudevillians Mr. Amendola (Jimmy Durante), his wife (Queenie Smith), and teenage daughter Rosalinda (Terry Moore) move into a cramped apartment run by miserly Mr. Dingle (Frank Orth) who lives in the house next door with his wife (Sara Haden) and teenage son (Tom Drake).Miser that he is, Dingle's been socking away thousands of dollars behind a loose baseboard. Now, beyond that baseboard is the attic - and in that very attic lives the Great Rupert, a trained squirrel owned by the apartment's former tenant. The greenbacks begin to clutter Rupert's living space - so as quick as Mr. Dingle stuffs them in - the Great Rupert throws them out...where they go drifting through a hole in Jimmy Durante's roof.Meanwhile, Christmas is coming, and the Amendola family is down on its luck. Mrs. Amendola sits alone, praying to the Lord, "Rosalinda needs new shoes". Suddenly, money begins falling from Heaven through the hole in the roof.The Great Rupert would be a welcome addition to any film buff's Classic Christmas 'B-Team', along with "Bob Hope's "The Lemon-Drop Kid", Cary Grant in "The Bishop's Wife" and "Christmas In Connecticut" starring Barbara Stanwyck.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is an entertaining story demonstrating Durante's humor and entertainment ability  A classic in film and fun to watch too

reviewText: I have this movie in it's digitally restored, remastered and colorized version "A Christmas Wish". The skin tones aren't exactly right, but I like it better than the black and white version.It is a charming, funny and sometimes touching movie. The version I have also includes a commentary with Terry Moore, which funny and insightful. Tom Drake from Meet Me in St Louis is also in this move.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Christmas, an adorable dancing squirrel, and the incomprable Jimmy Durante -- what more could you want?  Durante plays Papa, head of the Amendola clan.  It's Christmas Eve and the Amendolas are in a bad way: homeless and down to their last 40 cents.  Papa sweet talks mean landlord Dingle into renting them an apartment even though they have no money.  The deeply religious Mama prays for Divine Intervention and gets it -- money rains down from Heaven!  Actually, it's raining down from the attic.  Unbeknownst to all, Rupert the Dancing Squirrel has holed up in the apartment's attic and the fastidious little fellow is simply cleaning house, throwing out the money that skinflint Dingle hides there.  The Amendola's lifestyle greatly improves as does much of the communitiy's as the kindheard Papa shores up failing local businesses by investing in them.  The town's busybodies do some wild speculating about the familiy's new found riches which attracts the attention of the IRS, FBI, and local police.  But all ends well for everybody, even Rupert.  This silly plot is the basis for one of the most charming, heart-warming movies you'll ever see.  The entire cast is good and Durante, as always, steals every scene he's in.  He gets off the movie's funniest lines and sings several songs in his inimitable style.  His rendition of "Jingle Bells" is a knockout.  George Pal's Academy Award winning special effects may seem primitive now but they were state of the art then and bring Rupert to delightful life.  This bargain priced DVD from Alpha has good sound and picture quality.  Start a Christmas tradition:  gather the family around the TV, have some cookies and hot chocolate, and watch "The Great Rupert" as you wait for Santa to arrive.  Outstanding.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you and yours are ready for a new holiday movie; Must be family friendly, but need not be overly gooey and soppy, The Great Rupert is an easy recommendation.Last of the great vaudevillians, Jimmy Durante (Louis Amendola) head of an out of work family stage act comes to rest in a dilapidated apartment attached to the home of his stingy landlord played by Frank Orth (Frank Dingle). The combination of potentially deadbeats theatricals and a miserly landlord would be a short movie except:Terry Moore (Rosalinda Amendola) as the lovely stage daughter falls for the moony would be musician, landlord's son played by Tom Drake (Pete Dingle).  And then there is Rupert. A trained dancing squirrel filmed in a clever mix of live and stop action animation.Having been temporarily abandoned by his stage partner and human companion, Rupert moves back into their former apartment. There Rupert has his stash of winter food and a punctilious need to keep his nest free of paper.Our landlord comes into some money and with just a hint of movie magic so does the Amendola family. In the case of the tenants, the money is literally the answer to a prayer... Amen Dole or is that too much of a pun?For the rest there is love in the air, Jimmy Durante on the piano and a good time to be had by all.When folks talk about how they `Used" to make `em, The Great Rupert is one of the ones the speaker has in mind. This is family night, bed time with the kiddies easy on the grey cells entertainment. Just enough laughs and very little of drama. And then there is "The Great Snozola", Jimmy Durante on the piano.
summary: A new old movie for your family Christmas Holidays
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are looking for a movie to watch on Christmas day with your family, in addition to the well known Christmas classics of your collection, I would recommend this unknown movie starring Jimmy Durante. This is a heart warming story of a true Christmas spirit, much similar to Scrooge, involving the family of Mr. Amendola (Jimmy Durante), his wife Mrs. Amendola (Quinie Smith), and their only daughter Rosalinda (Terry Moore.) Jimmy Durante offers a brilliant performance as a faded vaudeville star who rents an apartment just before Christmas holidays during Great depression. With serious financial problem on one hand, on the other, they face the challenges of their penny pinching land lord, Mr. Dingle (Frank Orth) who is interested in collecting the rent money but not fix the apartment. He is a real Scrooge in person! But his wife Mrs. Dingle (Sara Haden) and their only son Peter Dingle (Tom Drake) are very compassionate and caring. One day during the prayer of Mrs. Dingle, she a finds large amount of cash ($100 bills) falling through the big hole on her roof. The family comes to believe that it is cash from heaven, a true Christmas miracle indeed! Actually this money belongs to Dingle who gets a check from his gold mine stock every week, and hides the cash in his attic which is innocently tossed by a squirrel named Rupert. Rupert belongs to the last resident of the apartment, Joe Mahoney (Jimmy Conklin) and The Great Rupert was his vaudeville act. This squirrel returns to the apartment when Joe releases him because he doesn't have a job and no money!Mr. Amendola uses his suddenly found riches to help the community by starting various businesses and offer employment. Every one in town gets suspicious about his wealth including; local law enforcing authority, IRS, and FBI. In the meantime, when Dingle losses on his investment, the checks stop coming and his luck turns ugly. When his house burns in an accidental fire; he believes that all his hidden stash is lost. Then the kind hearted Amendola steps in to help him rebuild the house. At the same time the authorities find the case of Amendola's wealth is complex to solve and hard to prosecute, and they decide to leave him alone.Tom Dingle who is in love with Rosalinda does everything to impress her, and to his disappointment she dates a wealthy song promoter named Chick Chandler (Phil Davis), but in reality she is in love with Peter Dingle, a penniless songwriter. The movie pitches the kind hearted souls of Amendola family and Dingle family together to teach the true spirit of Christmas to Mr. Dingle and the law enforcement agencies. The highlight of the movie also includes the special-effects of pioneer George Pal, and the technique of animated puppetry to bring life to the title character a lovable squirrel that rescues a family of vaudeville performers during the Christmas time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I remember watching these movies when the family would come over for the Hoildays,or over the weekend after dinner.The family loved Jimmy and I always loved watching everyone having such a great time.There is something about these movies I guess you could call charming.What a great movie this is and l hope to see more like this come back!
summary: They don't make movies like they used to

reviewText: "The Great Rupert" is a great movie.  It is unique in the annals of film history and has the most personable squirrel in the history of celluloid.  I've been trying to train one of the squirrels that hangs around my house to act like the Great Rupert and throw down hundred dollar bills.The service was fabulous.
